item.title: Searching 1 billion embeddings from disk in 15 ms on a single machine
item.description: In my last post, I built a semantic map of 4 million Hacker News posts and dived deep into semantic search and AI embeddings. Continuing the fun research and hacking in this space, in this post, I'll deep dive into how vector search works with interactive visualizations (and the interesting theory behind them), the limitations of current approaches, and how I ended up building a vector DB called CoreNN. It's able to search through 1 billion Reddit comment embeddings in 15 ms from a 4.8 TB index on disk‚Äîall time is spent embedding the query and fetching results:

item.title: Language model benchmarks only tell half a story
item.description: When it comes to language models, we tend to look at benchmarks to decide which model is the best to use in our application. But benchmarks only tell half a story. Unless you're building an all-purpose chat application, what you should be actually looking at is how well a model works for your application.

item.title: Verified Dynamic Programming with Œ£-types in Lean
item.description: 1. IntroductionIf you‚Äôve taken an algorithms class, you have likely seen dynamic programming, specifically a technique called memoization. Memoization works to optimize recursive algorithms by caching the solutions to subproblems in a table, and when a subproblem is encountered, it queries the table instead of recomputing the solution. This gives us an exponential performance boost.

item.title: GETting Conditionally - The Bare Basics
item.description: A while ago, a prominent Vercel employee (two, actually) posted to the tune of: Developers don‚Äôt get CDNs Exhibit A etc. It is often that random tweets somehow get me into a frenzy ‚Äì somebody is wrong on the internet, yet again. But when I gave this a second thought, I figured that‚Ä¶ this statement has more merit than I would have wanted it to have. It has merit because we do not know the very basics of cache control that are necessary (and there are not that many)! It does not have merit in the sense that force-prefetching all of your includes through Vercel‚Äôs magic RSC-combine will not, actually, solve all your problems. They are talking in solutions that they sell, and what they are not emphasizing is that the issue is with the ‚Äúdeveloper slaps ‚ÄòCache-Control‚Äô‚Äù part. Moreover: as I will explain, a lot of juice can be squeezed out of you by CDN providers exactly because your cache control is not in order and they offer you tools that kind of ‚Äúforce‚Äù your performance back into a survivable state. With some improvement for your users, and to the detriment of your wallet. But first, let‚Äôs rewind and see what those CDNs actually do. CDNs use something called ‚Äúconditional GET requests‚Äù. Conditional GET requests mean: Cache-Control. And even I, in my hubris, haven‚Äôt been using it correctly. After reviewing how it worked on a few of my own sites, I have overhauled my uses ‚Äì and built up a ‚Äúminimum understanding‚Äù of it which has been, to say the least, useful. So, there it is: the absolute bare minimum of Cache-Control knowledge you may need for a public, mostly-static (CMS-driven, let‚Äôs say) website. Strap in, this is going to be wild. And be mindful of one thing: I do not work for Vercel, CloudFlare, AWS or Fastly. I just like fast websites and I think you deserve to have your website go fast as well.

item.title: 2025-06-16 Ban autonomous systems
item.description: More people have been working on blocking whole ranges of IP numbers, since that catches hosting providers that give bots access to the whole range they control. The bots switch IP numbers all the time so a filter based on IP numbers won‚Äôt catch them. But if we can determine their autonomous system number (ASN), we can not only block an IP number range, we can block all the IP number rangers the ASN controls.

item.title: My Formatter Will Never Be As Fast As Ruff
item.description: I've been building a universal code formatter in Zig, and I recently discovered something humbling: my formatter will never be as fast as Ruff on large files. But here's the twist - it's actually faster on small files, and the journey to this realization taught me a lot.

item.title: Honda Conducts Successful Launch and Landing Test of Experimental Reusable Rocket | Honda Global Corporate Website
item.description: Honda Global | Honda R&D Co., Ltd., a research and development subsidiary of Honda Motor Co., Ltd., today conducted a launch and landing test of an experimental reusable rocket*1 (6.3 m in length, 85 cm in diameter, 900 kg dry weight/1,312 kg wet weight) developed independently by Honda. The test was completed successfully, the first time Honda landed a rocket after reaching an altitude of 300 meters.
